Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Groups, Poisson Lie Groups, and Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal addresses series of interrelated problems on quantum groups, Poisson Lie groups, Poisson homogeneous spaces, and their relations to combinatorics. These include: determining the spectra of quantized universal enveloping algebras of nilpotent algebras of De Concini-Kac-Procesi and Lusztig and the Berenstein-Zwicknagl (flat) braided symmetric algebras, carring out the orbit method for quantized algebras of functions, classifying automorphism groups of quantum nilpotent algebras, investigating quantized algebras of functions related to the Belavin-Drinfeld classification and the corresponding varieties of Lagrangian subalgebras, proving completeness of Kogan-Zelevinsky integrable systems, investigating cluster algebras on flag varieties and double flag varieties and their interaction with total positivity on these objects.


The theory of Lie and algebraic groups is a major branch of mathematics, used to study in a unified way symmetries of physical theories, and geometric and algebraic objects. In recent years noncommutative versions of these techniques started playing an increasingly prominent role. Hopf algebras appeared in numerous studies in mathematical physics, algebra, combinatorics, noncommutative geometry, and topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of Lie and algebraic groups is a major branch of mathematics used to study in a unified way symmetries of physical theories, and of geometric and algebraic objects. In recent years noncommutative versions of these techniques played a major role. In particular, Quantum Groups appeared in numerous studies in mathematical physics, algebra, combinatorics, noncommutative geometry, and topology. Cluster Algebras form another axiomatic family invented by Sergey Fomin and Andrei Zelevinsky that is used to investigate the objects in the above mentioned areas of mathematics and mathematical physics.

The intelectual merit of the project outcomes for this grant is as follows:

The PI setteled the Andruskiewitsch-Dumas and Launois-Lenagan conjectures on the classification of symmetries of quantum algebras. He constructed a Dixmier type map from symplectic foliations of Poisson Lie groups to the primitive spectra of all quantum groups. This provided the first explicit map towards the realization of the orbit method for quantum groups, an open problem since 1993.The PI also proved the Goodearl-Lenagan conjecture that all torus invariant prime ideals of the quantum Schubert cell algebras have polynormal generating sequences. Using it, the PI proved that all quantum Schubert cell algebras are catenary. This is a far reaching extension of a major theorem of Gabber on catenarity of universal enveloping algebras of solvable Lie algebras. The PI classified the maximal spectra of all quantum groups, which was again a long standing problem from the early 90s. He settled positively the Goodearl-Zhang problem that the maximal ideals of all quantum groups should have finite codimension. The PI furthermore obtained many additional results on the topology of the spectra of quantum groups and quantum Schubert cell algebras.

The PI and K. R. Goodearl proved that every algebra in a very large axiomatic family of algebras possesses cluster algebra structure. This had many applications, among which was a proof of the Berenstein-Zelevinsky conjecture on the existence of cluster algebra structures on all double Buhat cells. Another application  was the construction of cluster algebra structures on all quantum unipotent groups, which extended a result of Geiss, Leclerc and Schroer for the case of symmetric Kac-Moody algebras.  The PI and Goodearl also settled positive the problem about whether all cluster algebras of Berenstein, Fomin and Zelevinsky associated to double Bruhat cells are equal to the correspodning upper cluster algebras.

The PI resolved positively the problem about whether all cluster algebras of Berenstein, Fomin and Zelevinsky associated to double Bruhat cells admit maximal green sequences in the sense of B. Keller. This has many important applications to the structure of these cluster algebras. The PI and T. H. Lenagan found explicit models for the prime factors of all quantum Schubert cell algebras. They also constructed cluster algebra structures on all quantum Richardson varieties.

The PI in collaboration with D. Grantcharov and I. Dimitrov obtained classification results for cominuscule parabolic subalgebras of all complex simple Lie superalgebras and a Belavin-Drinfeld type classification for the quasitriangular Lie bialgebra structures on all complex simple Lie superalgebras. The PI and E Horozov classified all rank one bispectral operators with values in every finite dimensional algebra A. This lead to a construction of a Calogero-Moser spaces associated to every such algebra A.

The broader impacts of the activities associated to this grant are as follows: The PI supervised 5 Ph.D. students Joel Geiger (Ph.D. 2013), Eric Bucher, Maitreyee Kulkarni, Jesse Levitt and Bach Nguyen (ongoing).
